now.title: What is on my desk right now

cards.label: Currently building
cards.text: A personal platform around homelab operations with GitOps delivery and immutable image-based host updates.

cards.label: Reliability obsession
cards.text: Tight feedback loops: every change must be observable, reproducible, and easy to roll back.

cards.label: Learning loop
cards.text: Deep-diving eBPF and OpenTelemetry to understand behavior beyond dashboards and logs.

cards.label: Personal rule
cards.text: If a task repeats more than twice, I automate it or document it as a scriptable runbook.

stack.title: Tech stack matrix
stack.hint: Filter by domain to see what I rely on every day.

items.name: Go
items.role: Primary language for services and automation.
items.note: Fast feedback, strong tooling, static binaries, predictable performance.

items.name: TypeScript
items.role: Glue language for UI and API boundaries.
items.note: Makes interfaces explicit and safer across the stack.

items.name: Astro
items.role: Framework for content-first and high-performance pages.
items.note: Minimal runtime by default keeps pages fast and maintainable.

items.name: Tailwind CSS
items.role: Styling system for fast iterations with clear constraints.
items.note: Keeps visual language consistent without heavy custom CSS.

items.name: Kubernetes
items.role: Core platform for scheduling and service operations.
items.note: I treat manifests as product artifacts, not just deployment files.

items.name: FluxCD
items.note: Desired state in Git gives safer changes and clear audit trails.

items.name: Terraform
items.note: Declarative foundation so environments stay reproducible.

items.name: GitHub Actions
items.note: Quality gates run early so production stays boring.

items.name: Prometheus
items.note: If I cannot measure it, I do not trust it in production.

items.name: Grafana
items.note: Dashboards are for navigation, alerts are for action.

items.name: OpenTelemetry
items.note: Building shared telemetry conventions across projects.

items.name: bootc
items.role: Image-based host lifecycle for immutable systems.
items.note: Pushing host management toward the same discipline as apps.

items.name: Neovim
items.note: Keyboard-first workflows reduce friction during deep work.

items.name: Zed
items.role: Secondary editor for pair sessions and quick context switching.
items.note: Useful for speed, especially when reviewing unfamiliar code.

items.name: PostgreSQL
items.note: Reliable, boring, and feature-rich for real systems.

items.name: Redis
items.note: Best when used intentionally and with strict expiry rules.

items.title: Simple scales
items.text: The most resilient systems are usually the easiest to explain on a whiteboard.

items.title: Observe before you optimize
items.text: Most performance work starts with wrong assumptions. Instrumentation prevents wasted effort.

items.title: Automate the boring path
items.text: Humans should review intent, not click through repetitive deployment steps.

items.title: Write for future me
items.text: Clear docs and runbooks beat perfect memory every single time.

work.title: How I move from idea to production
work.mission_text: Building a reproducible cloud-native baseline that unifies local development, homelab infrastructure, and production-style operations.

steps.title: Discover
steps.text: Collect real pain points from daily operations and convert them into concrete engineering constraints.

steps.title: Design
steps.text: Draft the smallest architecture that can survive real traffic, incidents, and maintenance.

steps.title: Ship
steps.text: Deliver in thin slices with CI gates, progressive rollout, and rollback safety.

steps.title: Observe
steps.text: Track latency, errors, and cost continuously, then feed that data into the next iteration.
